contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) "has become as small as a hut in a vineyard or a shed in a garden of cucumbers" or 2) "is left the way a farmer leaves a hut in a vineyard or a shed in a garden of cucumbers when he is finished with them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: is left like a hut in a vineyard, like a shed in a garden of cucumbers

contextId.occurrenceNote: Scarlet is a bright red color. Alternate translation: "bright red" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like scarlet

contextId.occurrenceNote: White is often a symbol for holiness or purity. "Snow" refers to something like frozen rain that is very white. Since this simply describes something as very white, you could replace it with something else that is white: "white as a seashell" or "white as a dove." This means that their sins will be forgiven. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: white like snow

contextId.occurrenceNote: Crimson is a dark red color. Alternate translation: "dark red" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: red like crimson

contextId.occurrenceNote: Water gives life to trees and gardens. The people have cut themselves off from Yahweh, who gives them life. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: For you will be like an oak whose leaf fades, and like a garden that has no water

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the person's deeds or evil works to a spark that falls on tinder and sets it on fire. Alternate translation: "his work will be like a spark that starts a fire" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: his work like a spark

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the people of Judah are said to be like the people of Sodom, because they openly boasted about their sins. Alternate translation: "like the people of Sodom, they talk about their sins and let everyone know about them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: they tell of their sin like Sodom; they do not hide it

contextId.occurrenceNote: That is, the lambs will graze there. The land will be worthless for any other use. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: in the ruins, lambs will graze as foreigners

contextId.occurrenceNote: The dead bodies are allowed to lie in the streets as if they were garbage. This implies that many will die but that no one will be there to bury them. The word "garbage" can also be translated as "refuse" or "manure." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: their corpses are like garbage in the streets

contextId.occurrenceNote: "their hooves are like hard stone." Isaiah compares the hard part of a horse's foot to flint, which is a hard stone that can cause sparks when struck. Possible meanings are 1) Isaiah compares their hooves to flint so to describe the frightening image of their feet causing sparks as they run or 2) Isaiah compares their hooves to flint to emphasize how strong their hooves are which enables the horse to do whatever their master want them to do. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: their horses' hooves are like flint

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah compares the chariot wheels to storms in order to imply that they will destroy everything in their path. Alternate translation: "the wheels of the chariots will spin like a windstorm" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: their chariot wheels like storms

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means that even after Yahweh destroys Israel, he will still set apart people from among the Israelites to serve him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as a terebinth or an oak is cut down and whose trunk remains, the holy seed is in its stump

contextId.occurrenceNote: The trembling of their hearts at this news is compared to the way trees shake when the wind blows through them. Alternate translation: "Ahaz and his people were very afraid" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: His heart trembled, and the heart of his people, as the trees of the forest shake in the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: The joy that Yahweh will give Israel is described as the same kind of joy people have when they bring in a harvest or divide valuable plunder. Alternate translation: "They will rejoice before you as people rejoice when they gather their crops or when a battle is over and soldiers divide what they took" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They rejoice before you like the joy at harvest time, as men rejoice when they divide the plunder

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) Yahweh compares the army of Assyria attacking Israel to people stomping through mud who do not care what happens to the mud. Alternate translation: "trample them until they become like mud" or 2) the people are stomping on other people so they are lying in the mud and unable to rise. This is a metaphor for completely defeating them. Alternate translation: "completely defeat them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: trample them like mud

contextId.occurrenceNote: "as strong as a bull." Some ancient texts read, "like a mighty man." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a bull

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king of Assyria compares taking the treasures from the nations to a person taking eggs out of a bird's nest. This emphasizes how easy it was for him and his army to conquer these other kingdoms. Alternate translation: "My army has stolen the wealth from the nations just as easily as a man takes eggs from a nest" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: My hand has seized, as from a nest, the wealth of nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king of Assyria speaks of taking over nations as if he was gathering eggs. Alternate translation: "just as a person takes eggs from a nest when the bird is not there to protect them, my army has taken the treasures of every nation" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as one gathers abandoned eggs, I gathered all the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the nations to a bird who sits quietly while her eggs are taken. This emphasizes that the nations did nothing while the army of Assyria took all of their possessions. Alternate translation: "And like a bird that does not make a sound or flap her wings when someone steals her eggs, the nations did nothing as we took their treasure" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: None fluttered their wings or opened their mouth or chirped

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares his punishment to a fire. This emphasizes that his punishment will completely destroy all the splendor and greatness of the kingdom of Assyria. Alternate translation: "I will destroy his greatness as if I were starting a fire to burn everything he is proud of" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: under his glory there will be kindled a burning like fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares either the forests and farmlands of Assyria or the army of Assyria to a sick man as he lies in bed dying. This emphasizes how something so great can become weak and dying. Alternate translation: "they will be like a sick man who grows weak and dies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: it will be like when a sick man's life wastes away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This emphasizes that there were a great number of people of Israel. Alternate translation: "are too many to count, like the sand on the seashore" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: are like the sand of the seashore

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase is used to show how full the earth will be of people who know Yahweh. It may be clearer that it does this if its words are similar to the words in the previous phrase. Alternate translation: "as the seas are full of water" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as the waters cover the sea

contextId.occurrenceNote: A banner is a flag that a king would raise as a sign for people to see it and come to him. Alternate translation: "will be like a sign for the peoples" or "will attract the peoples to come to him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: will stand as a banner for the peoples

contextId.occurrenceNote: A branch thrown away represents something worthless. Alternate translation: "like a worthless branch that is tossed aside" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a branch thrown away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents many dead bodies being on top of his body. Alternate translation: "The bodies of dead people completely cover your body" or "The bodies of dead soldiers are piled on top of your body" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: The dead cover you like a garment

contextId.occurrenceNote: All the people of Moab, which includes the women, are forced to flee from their homes. Alternate translation: "Like birds without a home, the women of Moab will flee across the river to another land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: As wandering birds, as a scattered nest, so the women of Moab are at the fords of the Arnon River

contextId.occurrenceNote: There will be nothing left in the land after God punishes the people of Israel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: It will be as when a harvester gathers the standing grain ... in the Valley of Rephaim

contextId.occurrenceNote: People harvested olive trees by shaking them so that the olives would fall out. Alternate translation: "like the few olives that remain on the olive trees after people harvest them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as when the olive tree is shaken

contextId.occurrenceNote: An uproar is a very loud noise. Alternate translation: "The sound of many people, that is very loud like the seas" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: The uproar of many peoples, that roar like the roaring of the seas

contextId.occurrenceNote: The enemy armies appear to be a powerful force that no one can stop. Alternate translation: "the nations come rushing in like the mighty waters" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: the rushing of nations, that rush like the rushing of mighty waters

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases show how quietly God will watch the nation. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like the simmering heat in sunshine, like a cloud of mist in the heat of harvest

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah speaks of the people of Egypt doing what is wrong as if they were made to wander about like a drunken person. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a drunk staggering in his vomit

contextId.occurrenceNote: This emphasizes that the people of Egypt will be afraid and helpless when God punishes them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Egyptians will be like women

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah compares the army that will attack the people to a storm with strong winds. They will be quick and powerful. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Like stormwinds sweeping through the Negev

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah compares his pain to the pain of a woman giving birth. This emphasizes the great pain he is feeling. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: pains like the pains of a woman in labor have taken hold of me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) Isaiah is telling the people of Tarshish to start planting crops since they can no longer trade with Tyre or 2) Isaiah is telling the people of Tarshish they are free from Tyre's control. Alternate translation: "Pass through your land like a river, daughter of Tarshish. The people of Tyre no longer have any power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Plow your land, as one plows the Nile, daughter of Tarshish. There is no longer a marketplace in Tyre

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the nations after Yahweh devastates the land to trees and vines after their fruit has been picked. This means there will be very few people left in the land. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as when an olive tree is beaten, as the gleanings when the grape harvest is done

contextId.occurrenceNote: These similes emphasize how the earth will shake back and forth. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: The earth will stagger like a drunken man and it will sway back and forth like a hut

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ruthless people oppressing the people of God is spoken of as if they were a storm beating against a wall. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: When the breath of the ruthless was like a storm against a wall

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the enemies of God's people to the heat that dries up the land. This emphasizes how much the enemies cause the people of God to suffer. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like heat in a dry land

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh stopping ruthless people from singing and boasting is compared to a cloud providing shade on a hot day. This emphasizes that Yahweh comforts his people by stopping those who cause them to suffer. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as the heat is subdued ... ruthless ones is answered

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile emphasizes how badly Yahweh will humiliate the people of Moab. They will spread their hands in dung like a swimmer spreads his hands in water. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They will spread their hands ... his hands to swim

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the people to a woman giving birth. This emphasizes their suffering and crying when Yahweh disciplined them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: As a pregnant woman ... cries out in her labor pains

contextId.occurrenceNote: "but it is as if we have only given birth to air" or "it is like we gave birth to nothing." This is a simile that emphasizes that the people's suffering resulted in nothing. Alternate translation: "but nothing good resulted from it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: but it is as if we have only given birth to wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: A "storm of hail" or hailstorm happens when hard pieces of ice fall from the sky. Here it is a simile that refers to the enemy army that Yahweh will send to destroy the people of Samaria. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: storm of hail

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the enemy soldiers seeing the beauty of Samaria and quickly plundering it as if they were a person who sees the first fig of the season and quickly eats it. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: will be as the first ripe fig ... gulps it down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Translators may add a footnote that says, "The name Ariel means 'altar.'" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like Ariel

contextId.occurrenceNote: All of these statements mean basically the same thing. They emphasize that the people who once spoke with proud words will be weak and grieving after the enemy defeats them. Alternate translation: "you will only be able to speak with weak whispers like a spirit speaking from where dead people dwell" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: will speak from the ground; your speech will be low from the dust. Your voice will sound like a spirit that speaks from the ground, and out of the dust your speech will whisper

contextId.occurrenceNote: This emphasizes how weak and insignificant the invading army is before God. Alternate translation: "Yahweh will easily remove the horde of your invaders and the multitude of the ruthless ones"(See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: The great number of your invaders will become like fine dust, and the multitude of the ruthless ones as chaff that passes away

contextId.occurrenceNote: These similes mean that the enemy will expect victory but they will fail because God will not allow them to conquer Jerusalem. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: It will be like when a hungry man dreams he is eating ... his thirst not quenched

contextId.occurrenceNote: The other prophets in Jerusalem are unable to hear or understand God's message. Alternate translation: "All that Yahweh has revealed is to you like a sealed book" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: All revelation has become to you as the words of a book that is sealed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means that God will destroy the people of Judah suddenly because of their sin. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: so this sin will be to you like a broken part ... in an instant

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means that the piece of wall will break as quickly and completely as a clay jar that falls to the ground. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as a potter's vessel is broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means there will be so few people left that they will be like a single flag on top of a hill. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: until your remnant will be like a flagstaff on the top of a mountain, or like a flag on a hill

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile means they will throw away their idols like they were garbage. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: You will throw them away like a menstrual rag

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the air coming out of Yahweh's mouth to a flood to emphasize its power to destroy. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: His breath is like an overflowing torrent

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile emphasizes how happy the people will be. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as in the night when a holy feast is observed

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile emphasizes how happy the people will be. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as when one goes ... Rock of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh's breath as if it were a river of fire that will set the pile on fire. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: The breath of Yahweh, like a stream of brimstone, will set it on fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: "A lion ... in the same way Yahweh of hosts." Here Yahweh speaks of how he will defend the people who belong to him and not be scared away by comparing himself to a lion who guards it's prey. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: As a lion ... thus Yahweh of hosts

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the way that Yahweh protects Jerusalem is compared to the way that a mother bird protects her baby birds in their nest. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Like birds in flight, so Yahweh of hosts will protect Jerusalem

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the king and princes who protect the people to a shelter. Alternate translation: "the rulers will protect the people like a shelter does in a storm" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Each one will be like a shelter from the wind and a refuge from the storm

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is another comparison that means that the rulers will provide for the needs of the people. Alternate translation: "they will provide for the people like streams of water in a dry place" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like streams of water in a dry place

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is another comparison that means that the rulers will provide comfort and rest for the people. Alternate translation: "they will provide rest for the people like a huge rock gives shade to weary people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like the shade of a great rock in a land of weariness

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares how quick and eager Yahweh's people are when they gather the spoils from their enemies to the eagerness of locusts when they gather food. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Your people gather spoils from your enemies with the same fierceness as the locusts have who devour green plants" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Your spoil is gathered as the locusts gather; as locusts leap, men leap on it

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares how dry Sharon is to a desert plain. Alternate translation: "Sharon is as dry as a desert plain" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Sharon is like a desert plain

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares how the peoples' dead bodies will be burned to the way thornbushes are burned. Also, this can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Fire will burn the peoples' bodies to lime in the same way that a farmer cuts down thornbushes and burns them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: The peoples will be burned to lime, as thornbushes are cut down and are burned

contextId.occurrenceNote: This emphasizes even the things in the sky that people thought would be there forever will fall as easily as a leaf. Alternate translation: "all the stars will fall from the sky like a leaf falls from a vine or a fig falls from a tree" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: all their stars will fade away, as the leaf fades from off the vine, and as the overripe figs from the fig tree

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the way the plants of the desert blossom to the way a rose (verse 1) has many blossoms. Alternate translation: "The desert will grow many new plants and trees" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: it will blossom abundantly

contextId.occurrenceNote: Deer can jump far and high. Jumping like a deer is an exaggeration for being able to move about quickly and easily. Alternate translation: "the lame man will jump high" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: the lame man will leap like a deer

contextId.occurrenceNote: This comparison is made to emphasizes that they are in a time of extreme difficulty. Alternate translation: "It is as terrible as the day when a child is ready to be born, but the mother has no strength to give birth to her child" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like when a child is ready to be born, but the mother has no strength to give birth to her child

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of how Yahweh is ending Hezekiah's life quickly by comparing it to how a shepherd removes his tent from the ground. Alternate translation: "Yahweh has taken my life away from me quickly like a shepherd packs up his tent and carries it away" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: My life is removed and carried away from me like a shepherd's tent

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of Yahweh quickly ending Hezekiah's life by comparing it to how a weaver cuts his cloth from the loom and rolls it up. Alternate translation: "you are ending my life quickly, like a weaver cuts his cloth from the loom when it is finished" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I have rolled up my life like a weaver; you are cutting me off from the loom

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hezekiah speaks of how he is in extreme pain by comparing it to having his body torn apart by lions. Alternate translation: "my pain was as though I were being torn apart by lions" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a lion he breaks all my bones

contextId.occurrenceNote: The speaker compares the covenant faithfulness of people to flowers that bloom and then die quickly. The abstract noun "faithfulness" can be stated as "faithful." See how you translated "covenant faithfulness" in [Isaiah 16:5](../16/05.md). Alternate translation: "they quickly stop being faithful to the covenant, just like a flower of the field dies quickly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: all their covenant faithfulness is like the flower of the field

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet compares the nations to a drop of water and to dust in order to emphasize how small and insignificant they are to Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: the nations are like a drop in a bucket, and are regarded like the dust on the scales

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prophet compares the way Yahweh considers humans to the way humans would consider grasshoppers. Just as grasshoppers are small to humans, humans are small and weak before God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: the inhabitants are like grasshoppers before him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile extends the metaphor of the rulers as plants and Yahweh as the wind that causes them to wither. The wind of Yahweh's judgement will remove the withered plants as easily as wind blows away straw. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: the wind carries them away like straw

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares the way in which this person will trample the other rulers with the way that a potter tramples on clay to mix it with water. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a potter who is treading on the clay

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is compared with a warrior who is ready to defeat his people's enemies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh will go out as a warrior; as a man of war

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's activity as a shouting warrior is compared with a pregnant woman who cries from labor pains. This emphasizes sudden unavoidable action after a period of inactivity. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I will cry out like a woman in labor; I will gasp and pant

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares the magicians and sorcerers to straw that burns quickly in a fire. This means that Yahweh will destroy them as easily as fire burns stubble, and so they are powerless to save Babylon. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: they will become like stubble. The fire will burn them up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh compares the tightness of their neck muscles and the hardness of their foreheads to the hardness of iron and bronze. Here, to have a tight neck or a hard forehead is a metaphor that means the people are stubborn. Alternate translation: "it is as if your necks were iron and your heads were bronze" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: your neck muscles tight as iron, and your forehead like bronze

contextId.occurrenceNote: The servant compares himself with a student who learns from his teacher. Possible meanings are 1) "like one who learns from his teacher" or 2) "like one whom he has taught" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: like those who are taught

contextId.occurrenceNote: All of these refer to things that quickly and easily disappear or become useless. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like smoke ... like a garment ... like flies

contextId.occurrenceNote: This phrase compares men to grass to emphasize that their lives are short and that they die quickly. Alternate translation: "who live and die quickly like grass" or "who will wither and disappear like grass" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: who are made like grass

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the children being exhausted and helpless as if they were an antelope caught in a trap. Alternate translation: "they are helpless, like an antelope caught in a net" or "as helpless as a trapped antelope" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like an antelope in a net

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the way their enemies walked on their back to the way people walk on the street. Alternate translation: "you lay in the streets so your enemies could walk on your backs" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: you made your back like the ground and like the street for them to walk on

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "he" refers to God's servant whom Isaiah compares to a very young tree. This emphasizes that he will appear weak. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: For he grew up before Yahweh like a sapling

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sheep often leave the path on which the shepherd leads them. Isaiah means that we do what we want instead of what God commands. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: We all like sheep have gone astray

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah compares the servant to a lamb and a sheep to emphasize that he will remain silent as people harm and humiliate him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as a lamb that is led to the slaughter, and as a sheep that before its shearers is silent

contextId.occurrenceNote: This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "just as a lamb is silent as a person slaughters it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: as a lamb that is led to the slaughter

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the wicked to rough water on the shore that makes the water dirty. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: But the wicked are like the tossing sea ... mire and mud

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means shout loudly. Here "your" refers to Isaiah. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-you]])
contextId.glQuote: Lift up your voice like a trumpet

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means the person is bowing down, but he is not truly humble. "A reed" represents a weak plant that bends easily. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: A day for anybody to humble himself, for him to bow down his head like a reed

contextId.occurrenceNote: "A watered garden" represents abundance and plenty so they will have all they need. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: You will be like a watered garden

contextId.occurrenceNote: "A spring of water" represents a source of abundance in a land where water is precious. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a spring of water, whose waters never fail

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that because God is not coming to them, they feel helpless, not finding the right path and despairing of the future, with no hope for a vibrant life. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: We grope for the wall like the blind ... like dead men

contextId.occurrenceNote: These refer to the sounds the people made because they were distressed and mourning. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: We growl like bears and moan like doves

contextId.occurrenceNote: Narrow valleys in Judah were dry most of the year until a sudden, heavy rain turned them into fast-moving water. When that happened there was a lot of noise and wind. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: for he will come as a rushing stream

contextId.occurrenceNote: This comparison emphasizes that the speaker is extremely happy, joyful, celebrating. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as a bridegroom adorns himself with a turban, and as a bride adorns herself with her jewels

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both clauses reassure the people that God will eventually come and save the people of Israel and that it will be as apparent as light is. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: until her righteousness proceeds brightly, and her salvation as a burning torch

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sons" refers to the people of Israel and "you" refers to Judah, the land of Israel. This means the people will take possession of the land as a man takes possession of his young wife. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as a young man marries a young woman, so your sons will marry you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This emphasizes God's happiness about his relationship with his people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as a bridegroom rejoices over his bride, your God will rejoice over you

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that the people of Israel were sure-footed as horses in open country on their travels toward Israel from Egypt. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Like a horse running on flat land, they did not stumble

contextId.occurrenceNote: This image pictures cattle going into a valley where there is green grass and water and emphasizes that God led the people of Israel and took care of them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: As the cattle that go down into the valley ... rest

contextId.occurrenceNote: This possibly emphasizes how easily God's presence would have caused the mountains and the people to tremble. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hypo]])
contextId.glQuote: as when fire kindles the brushwood, or the fire makes water boil

contextId.occurrenceNote: A "menstrual rag" is a cloth that a woman uses during the time of month when she bleeds from her womb. This means all their attempts to please God fail. This sentence was meant to be shocking. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: all our righteous deeds are like a menstrual rag

contextId.occurrenceNote: Isaiah compares the people of Israel to leaves that dry up when dead. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: We have all withered like leaves

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means their sins, as a community, are the reason for their failure. Isaiah compares the iniquities to the wind as the force for their suffering Yahweh's punishment. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: our iniquities, like the wind, carry us away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means God will cause the people of the nations to bring a very large amount of riches, which will be permanent like a river and abundant. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a river ... like an overflowing stream

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Tender grass" grows fast and strong and compares to the health and vigor of God's faithful people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: will sprout like the tender grass

contextId.occurrenceNote: Storms represent Yahweh's powerful actions to make his judgment effective. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like the windstorm
